lesson.name: Lesson 4.5: Using Function Notation to Describe Rules, Part 2

page.title: 4.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will use rules of functions to find the output when the input is given (or to evaluate functions) and to find the input when the output is known (or to solve equations that define functions). To make connections between different representations of functions, you will interpret rules of functions by comparing cell phone data plans to choose the most cost-effective plan.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use technology to graph a function given in function notation, and use the graph to find the values of the function.
  • Be able to identify if a graph represents a function through the vertical line test.
  • Explain different ways to find the value of a function and to solve equations written in function notation.
  • Explain what makes a function a linear function.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.5.1: Finding Solutions of Equations
  • 4.5.2: Using the Vertical Line Test
  • 4.5.2: Self Check
  • 4.5.3: Comparing Functions
  • 4.5.3: Self Check
  • 4.5.4: Using Function Notation and Graphing Technology (Optional)
  • 4.5.4: Self Check
  • 4.5.5: Using Graphical and Algebraic Approaches for Finding Unknowns of Linear Functions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.5.6: Practice
  • 4.5.7: Lesson Summary

answer.answer_text: Next

page.title: 4.5.1: Finding Solutions of Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Consider the equation \(q = 4 + 0.8p\).

  1. What value of \(q\) would make the equation true when:
  1. \(p\) is 7?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(q=9.6\)


  1. \(p\) is 100?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(q=84\)


  1. What value of \(p\) would make the equation true when:

    1. \(q\) is 12?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(p=10\)


         b. \(q\) is 60?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(p=70\)

page.title: 4.5.2: Using the Vertical Line Test
page.contents:
Activity

A table for the relation \(f\) is below.

\(x\)

1

2

3

1

4

5

\(f\)

–1

5

–2

1

3

–2


  1. Is this relation a function? Explain your answer.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f\) is not a function because \(f(1) =-1\) and \(f(1)=1 \).




  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course.

    Interact with the graph. Graph the points in the relation on a coordinate grid.

Select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:




  1. What do you notice about the points \((1, -1)\) and \((1,1)\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are on the same vertical line.


VERTICAL LINE TEST

A set of points in a rectangular coordinate system is the graph of a function if every vertical line intersects the graph in at most one point.

If any vertical line intersects the graph in more than one point, the graph does not represent a function.

If the graph does represent a function, we say it “passes the vertical line test.”

  1. For the graphs below, tell if the graph passes the vertical line test and if it is the graph of a function.


a.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes, this passes the vertical line test and is a function.



b.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, this graph does not pass the vertical line test, and it is not a function. For example, the vertical line \(x=1\) crosses the graph more than once.


Notice that the graph of a line will always be a function. This is called a linear function.

Video: Interpreting Function Notation

Watch the following video to learn more about function notation.

page.title: 4.5.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following graphs is the graph of a function?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For a graph to be that of a function, it must pass the vertical line test. For this graph, there are multiple places where an imaginary vertical line would touch more than once. For example, the vertical line \(x = 2\) crosses the graph more than once. The answer is:

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For a graph to be that of a function, it must pass the vertical line test. For this graph, there are multiple places where an imaginary vertical line would touch more than once. For example, the vertical line \(x =2\) crosses the graph more than once. The answer is:
That’s correct! Check yourself: If an imaginary vertical line was drawn anywhere on the graph, it would only touch once. This graph passes the vertical line test and is the graph of a function.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For a graph to be that of a function, it must pass the vertical line test. For this graph, there are multiple places where an imaginary vertical line would touch more than once. For example, the vertical line \(x = 2\) crosses the graph more than once. The answer is:

answer.answer_text: I am not sure

page.title: 4.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determine If a Graph Is a Function


A relation is a function if every input has exactly one output value. So the relation defined by the equation \(y=2x−3\) is a function. Notice that a line will always be a function, so it is called a linear function.

If we look at the graph, each vertical dashed line intersects the line at only one point. This makes sense because in a function, for every \(x\)-value there is only one \(y\)-value.

If the vertical line hit the graph twice, the \(x\)-value would be mapped to two \(y\)-values, so the graph would not represent a function.

This leads us to the vertical line test. A set of points in a rectangular coordinate system is the graph of a function if every vertical line intersects the graph in at most one point. If any vertical line intersects the graph in more than one point, the graph does not represent a function.

Look at the graphs below:

Graph a passes the vertical line test because if an imaginary vertical line were drawn anywhere on the graph, it would only touch one time.

Graph a is a function.

Graph b does not pass the vertical line test because when a vertical line is drawn down the graph, there is at least one place where the vertical line touches twice.

Graph b is not a function.

Try It: Determine if a Graph Is a Function

Determine if each graph is a function. Use the vertical line test to explain.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.


Compare your answser:

Here is how to determine if a graph is a function:

Graph a does not pass the vertical line test because if a vertical line were drawn down the graph, there would be at least one place where the vertical line would touch more than once. For example, a vertical line drawn at \(x=1\) would cross the graph more than once.

Graph a is not a function.

Graph b does pass the vertical line test because a vertical line drawn anywhere on the graph will only touch one time.

Graph b is a function.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.5.3: Comparing Functions
page.contents:
A college student is choosing between two data plans for her new cell phone. Both plans include an allowance of 2 gigabytes of data per month. The monthly cost of each option can be seen as a function and represented with an equation:

  • Option A: \(A(x)=60\)
  • Option B: \(B(x)=10x+25\)

In each function, the input, \(x\), represents the gigabytes of data used over the monthly allowance.

  1. The student decides to find the values of \(A(1)\) and \(B(1)\) and compare them. What are those values?

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answer:

\(A(1) = 60\); \(B(1) = 35\)


  1. After looking at some of her past phone bills, she decided to compare \(A(7.5)\) and \(B(7.5)\). What are those values?

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answer:

\(A(7.5) = 60\); \(B(7.5) = 100 \)


  1. Describe each data plan in words.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Option A charges a flat fee of $60 each month. It doesn’t matter how many gigabytes of data are used. Option B charges a $25 fee plus $10 for each gigabyte of data over the 2-gigabytes allowance.



  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Interact with the graph below. Graph each function on the same coordinate plane. Then, explain which plan you think she should choose.

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

    1. She should choose Option A if she plans on using around 7.5 gigabytes a month.
    2. She should choose Option A if she uses more than 5.5 gigabytes a month (or more than 3.5 gigabytes over the allowance).
    3. She should choose Option B if she uses only about 2 gigabytes a month.

  1. The student only budgeted $50 a month for her cell phone. She thought, “I wonder how many gigabytes of data I would have for $50 if I go with Option B?” and wrote \(B(x)=50\). What is the answer to her question? Explain or show how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

2.5 gigabytes over the allowance (or 4.5 gigabytes in total). Your answers may vary, but here are some explanations:

    1. I used the graph to estimate the gigabytes of data when the cost is $50, and it is about 2.5.
    2. I knew that \(B(x)\) is equal to \(10x + 25\), so I wrote \(10x + 25 = 50\) and solved for \(x\), which gave \(x = 2.5\).

Extending Your Thinking

Describe a different data plan that, for any amount of data used, would cost no more than one of the given plans and no less than the other given plan. Explain or show how you know this data plan would meet these requirements.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples: 

The graph of this data plan would be a line whose slope is between the slope of the other two graphs (greater than 0 but less than 10) and goes through the intersection of the other two graphs.

The plan charges $4 for each gigabyte of data over the 2-gigabyte allowance, plus a $6 fee. With this plan:

  • If we use exactly 13.5 additional gigabytes above the allowance (that is, 5.5 gigabytes in total), all three plans would cost $60.
  • If we use less than that, our plan would cost less than Option A but more than Option B.
  • If we use more than that, our plan would cost more than Option A but less than Option B.

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.5.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Function Values

Functions are used in a variety of real-life situations. They are useful in making comparisons, especially when comparing the cost.

Example:
The daily cost to printing company A to print a book is modeled by a function \(C(x)=3.25x+1500\), where \(C\) is the total daily cost, in dollars, and \(x\) is the number of books printed.

Their competitor, company  B,  can print a book at a cost modeled by \(C(x)=2.75x+2500\).

Find \(C(1000)\) for each company and make a statement about the result.

Company A: \(C(1000)=3.25(1000)+1500\)

\(C=4750\)


Company B: \(C(1000)=2.75(1000)+2500\)

\( C=5250\)

When 1,000 books are printed, Company A has the better price.

Try It: Comparing Function Values

The daily cost to manufacturing company A is modeled by the function
\(C(x)=7.25x+2500\), where \(C(x)\) is the total daily cost and \(x\) is the number of items manufactured.

The daily cost to manufacturing company B is modeled by the function \(C(x)=8.5x +1500\).

Which company is less at \(C(1000)\)? Explain the meaning of the result.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answers may vary, but here are some examples:

Here is how to determine which company costs less at \(C(1000)\):

Substitute 1,000 in for \(x\) in each function.


Company A’s Cost Equation

\(C(x)=7.25x+2500\)

Substitute \(x=1000\)

\(C(1000)=7.25(1000)+2500\)

Simplify

\(C(1000)=9750\)


Company B’s Cost Equation

\(C(x)=8.5x +1500\)

Substitute \(x=1000\)

\(C(1000)=8.5(1000)+1500\)

Simplify

\(C(1000)=10,000\)

When 1,000 items are manufactured, Company A costs less.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.5.4: Using Function Notation and Graphing Technology (Optional)
page.contents:
Activity

The function \(B\) is defined by the equation \(B(x)=10x+25\). Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work:

  1. Find the value of each expression:

  1. \(B(6)\), and tell the window values for \(x\) and \(y\) that you used.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(6)=85\)


  1. \(B(2.75)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(2.75)=52.5\)


  1. \(B(1.482)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(1.482)=39.82\)


  1. Solve each equation:
  1. \(B(x)=93\), and tell the window values for \(x\) and \(y\) that you used.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x=6.8\)


  1. \(B(x)=42.1\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x=1.71\)


  1. \(B(x)=116.25\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x=9.125\)

page.title: 4.5.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding Missing Values

Function \(G\) is defined by \(G(x)=5x+20\). Find the following values using graphing technology.

  1. \(G(2)\)

To find \(G(2)\), look at \(x=2\) on the \(x\)-axis on the graph of \(G(x)\). Use proper steps with your graphing technology to find the \(y\)-value on the line: \(G(2)=30\).

  1. \(G(x)=32\)

To find the value of \(x\) where \(G(x)=32\), look at where the graph crosses the \(y\)-value of 32. Use proper steps with your graphing technology to find the \(x\)-value where the graph meets \(y=32\).


\(G(2.4)=32\)

Try It: Finding Missing Values

Function \(H\) is defined by \(H(x)=2x+4\). Find \(H(x)=10.4\) using graphing technology.



Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the value of \(H(x)\) using graphing technology:
To find the value of \(x\) where \(H(x)=10.4\), look at where the graph of \(H(x)=2x+4\) crosses the \(y\)-value of 10.4. Use proper steps with your graphing technology to find the \(x\)-value where the graph meets \(y=10.4\).

\(H(3.2)=10.4\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.5.5: Using Graphical and Algebraic Approaches for Finding Unknowns of Linear Functions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The college student who is looking for a data plan for her cell phone found a third option, which also offers a 2-gigabyte monthly allowance for data.

The monthly cost of this option can be represented by function \(C\), defined by \(C(x)=30x+5\), where \(x\) is the gigabytes of data used over the monthly allowance.

  1. Find \(C(0.7)\) and explain what it means in this situation. 

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(C(0.7)=26\) because \(30(0.7)+5=26\). Your answers may vary, but here is a possible explanation: It means that the cost would be $26 if she used 0.7 gigabyte over the 2-gigabytes allowance in a month.

  1. Her budget is still $50 a month. To find out how many gigabytes of data she could use if she chose this plan, she writes \(C(x)=50\) and solves for \(x\). What value of \(x\) makes this equation true? Show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

\(x=1.5\). Your answers may vary, but here is a possible explanation: Because \(C(x)=30x+5\), we can write \(C(x)=50\) as \(30x+5=50\) and solve for \(x\), which gives 1.5.

answer.answer_text: Previous
Next

page.title: 4.5.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use technology to graph a function given in function notation, and use the graph to find the values of the function.
  • Be able to identify if a graph represents a function through the vertical line test.
  • Explain different ways to find the value of a function and to solve equations written in function notation.
  • Explain what makes a function a linear function.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.5.1: Finding Solutions of Equations
    • In this activity, you evaluated functions at a specific input value to find the output.
  • 4.5.2: Using the Vertical Line Test
    • In this activity, you determined which graphs were functions based on the vertical line test.
  • 4.5.2: Self Check
  • 4.5.3: Comparing Functions
    • In this activity, you compared the values of two functions representing cell phone plans. You explained the function notation in words and graphed the functions.
  • 4.5.3: Self Check
  • 4.5.4: Using Function Notation and Graphing Technology (Optional)
    • In this activity, you used graphing technology to find the output value of a function given an input value. You also worked backward to find the input value given an output value of a function.
  • 4.5.4: Self Check
  • 4.5.5: Using Graphical and Algebraic Approaches for Finding Unknowns of Linear Functions
    • In this activity, you used graphical or algebraic approaches to find missing inputs or outputs. You explained the meaning of function notation in the given context.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.5.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

answer.answer_text: Previous
End of Lesson

page.title: 4.5.3: Self Check
page.contents: Rental car company A charges $50 a day plus $0.50 a mile, \(m\), and is modeled by function \(A\). Rental car company B charges $20 a day plus $1.00 a mile, \(m\), and is modeled by function \(B\). Which statement is true for the cost of one day after \(m\) miles?

answer.answer_text: \(A(100)>B(100)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(A(m)=50+0.50m\), \(B(m)=20+1m\) are the two equations, so \(A(100)=100\) and \(B(100)=120\). The answer is \(A(100)<B(100)\).

answer.answer_text: \(A(100)=B(100)\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(A(m)=50+0.50m\), \(B(m)=20+1m\) are the two equations, so \(A(100)=100\) and \(B(100)=120\). The answer is \(A(100)<B(100)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: \(A(m)=50+0.50m\), \(B(m)=20+1m\) are the two equations, so \(A(100)=100\) and \(B(100)=120\).

answer.answer_text: Company A is always more than Company B.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(A(m)=50+0.50m\), \(B(m)=20+1m\) are the two equations, so \(A(100)=100\) and \(B(100)=120\). The answer is \(A(100)<B(100)\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.5.6: Practice
page.contents:
1. The cell phone plan from Company C costs $10 per month, plus $15 per gigabyte for data used. The plan from Company D costs $80 per month, with unlimited data.

Rule \(C\) gives the monthly cost, in dollars, of using \(g\) gigabytes of data on Company C’s plan. Rule \(D\) gives the monthly cost, in dollars, of using \(g\) gigabytes of data on Company D’s plan.

  1. Which sentence describes the meaning of the statement \(C(2)=40\)?

Correct! It costs $40 to use 2 gigabytes of data using plan C.

Correct! It costs $40 to use 2 gigabytes of data using plan C.

The correct answer is It costs $40 to use 2 gigabytes of data using plan C.You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which is less, \(C(4)\)or \(D(4)\)?

Correct! \(C(4)\) is less. \(C(4)=70\) and \(D(4)=80\). The phone plan from Company C is less expensive if 4 gigabytes of data are used.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(C(4)\) is less. \(C(4)=70\) and \(D(4)=80\). The phone plan from Company C is less expensive if 4 gigabytes of data are used. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which is less, \(C(5)\) or \(D(5)\)?

Correct! \(D(5)\) is less. \(D(5)=80\) and \(C(5) =85\). The phone plan from Company D is less expensive if 5 gigabytes of data are used.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(D(5)\) is less. \(D(5)=80\) and \(C(5) =85\). The phone plan from Company D is less expensive if 5 gigabytes of data are used. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For what number \(g\) is \(C(g)=130\)?
    Enter Answer Here: Enter Only Integers

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.5.3–4.5.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Function \(G\) takes a student’s first name for its input and gives the number of letters in the first name for its output.
  1. Describe the meaning of \(G(\text{Jada})\). 

Correct! The name “Jada” has 4 letters.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.5.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the name “Jada” has 4 letters. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the value of \(G(\text{Diego})\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.5.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following graph a function?

 

Correct! Yes, this is a function because the graph passes the vertical line test.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Yes, this is a function because the graph passes the vertical line test. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following graph a function?

 

Correct! Yes, this is a function because the graph passes the vertical line test.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Yes, this is a function because the graph passes the vertical line test. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is the following graph a function?

 

Correct! No, this is not a function because the graph does not pass the vertical line test.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again

The correct answer is: No, this is not a function because the graph does not pass the vertical line test. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.5.4: Self Check
page.contents:
The function \(D\) is defined by the equation \(D(x)=2.5x +12\).

Which describes the window that can be used to find the value of \(x\) when \(D(x)=23.25\) using graphing technology and gives the correct value of \(x\)?

answer.answer_text: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(x=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 30, \(y\) from 0 to 100; \(x=70.125\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value 23.25 is the output value, not the input value. The window must include the value of \(D(x)\) and the estimated value of \(x\). The answer is: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 10, \(y\) from 20 to 25; \(x=4.5\).

answer.answer_text: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 10, \(y\) from 20 to 25; \(x=4.5\)
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Graph each equation using a window for \(y\)\ close to the given value and a window for \(x\) close to an estimated value. The value of \(x\) where the lines meet is 4.5.

answer.answer_text: Graph \(y=2.5x\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 10, \(y\) from 20 to 25; \(x=9.3\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: be sure to graph the full equation for \(D(x)\), using a window for \(y\) close to the given value and a window for \(x\) close to an estimated value. The answer is: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 10, \(y\) from 20 to 25; \(x=4.5\).

answer.answer_text: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 20 to 25, \(y\) from 0 to 10; \(x=4.5\)
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to use a window where you can see that given value of \(y\) and the estimated value of \(x\). The answer is: Graph \(y=2.5x+12\), \(y=23.25\); window: \(x\) from 0 to 10, \(y\) from 20 to 25; \(x=4.5\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.
